intro: Microchilus cajamarcae, commonly known as the Peruvian moonflower, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the high Andes of Peru. It is characterized by its small, white, star-shaped flowers that open at night, emitting a subtle fragrance. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and thrives in cool, moist environments with well-drained soil. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, known for its bell-shaped flowers. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
